s1.p: Base64 encoding converts binary data into text format using 64 printable ASCII characters (A-Z, a-z, 0-9, +, /), enabling safe transmission of binary data through text-only systems. Binary data is split into 6-bit groups, each mapped to base64 alphabet. Padding with '=' ensures output length is multiple of 4 characters. Base64 encoded data is approximately 33% larger than original—encoding adds overhead. Base64 is reversible—encoded text decodes back to original binary data perfectly. Base64 isn't encryption—encoded data is readable by anyone knowing the encoding. Base64 is compression-neutral—doesn't reduce or increase data size significantly.

s2.p: Base64 takes three bytes (24 bits) of binary data and splits into four 6-bit groups. Each 6-bit group (0-63) maps to base64 character set. Example: text 'ABC' converts to binary 01000001 01000010 01000011, splits to groups 010000 010100 001001 000011, mapping to base64 characters QUJD. If input isn't multiple of three bytes, padding occurs: two padding bytes add '==' to output, one padding byte adds '='. This process applies to entire input recursively. Understanding this mathematics helps troubleshoot encoding issues and recognize base64 patterns.

s3.p: Email systems use base64 encoding binary attachments enabling transmission through SMTP text protocol. Data URLs embed images directly in HTML/CSS using base64: data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGg... Web APIs sometimes accept base64-encoded files when file upload isn't available. Configuration files embed binary data as base64 text. Databases store base64-encoded binary data in text fields. API authentication uses base64 encoding for credentials. Legacy systems requiring text-only communication use base64 for binary data interchange. Modern systems increasingly avoid base64 in favor of binary protocols.

s4.p: Decoding reverses encoding process: each base64 character maps to 6-bit value. Four base64 characters combine into 24 bits split into three 8-bit bytes. Handling padding requires special logic—presence of '=' indicates incomplete byte groups requiring bit-shifting. Single '=' means last character group represents 2 bytes, double '==' means 1 byte. Decoding must validate input contains only base64 alphabet characters, failing on invalid characters. Most programming languages include native base64 encode/decode functions, eliminating manual implementation. Online tools provide convenient encoding/decoding without programming knowledge.

s5.p: Base64 encoding increases output size approximately 33% (4 characters for every 3 input bytes). Large files experience significant size increase—100MB binary becomes 133MB encoded. This size overhead impacts storage, bandwidth, and transmission time. Base64 should be avoided when file upload or binary protocol is available. Compressed base64 (compressing before encoding) sometimes reduces effective size overhead. Some systems prefer file transfer to base64 encoding despite protocol limitations. Modern systems increasingly use binary formats or file uploads rather than base64 for efficiency. Evaluate trade-offs between compatibility (base64 required) and efficiency (binary preferred).

s6.p: Base64 is encoding, not encryption—security is zero. Anyone with base64 string can instantly decode original data. Never rely on base64 for protecting sensitive information. If security is required, encrypt data before base64 encoding. Base64 prevents some attacks (random binary bytes corrupting text systems) but creates no inherent security. Base64 in URLs, emails, or logs provides zero confidentiality. For actual security, use proper encryption (AES-256) before base64 encoding if needed. Storing credentials in base64 (common with basic authentication) provides minimal security—use OAuth 2.0 or similar for production systems. Base64 is encoding convenience tool, not security mechanism.
